evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing. After the collision, she suggested not moving the aircraft off the blast fence.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident and consistently present during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as documented in the hist_dynamic_und_t3_prefinal scope.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew resists alternative interpretations or defeaters, as no other factors sufficiently explain the observed coordination failures in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_dynamic_und_t3_prefinal data.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, including misaligned task execution, delayed responses, and failure to share critical information timely.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and accessible within the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_dynamic_und_t3_prefinal dataset.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The procedural deviation in pushback execution withstands scrutiny against potential counterarguments or exceptions within the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_dynamic_und_t3_prefinal scope.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with the key features and operational parameters specific to the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_dynamic_und_t3_prefinal context.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident and consistently present during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as documented in the hist_dynamic_und_t3_prefinal scope.

assumptions: Lack of warnings and assumptions by crew members indicate communication breakdown.
Crew roles and qualifications imply expected communication standards.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination among crew during the incident.
If procedural deviations rather than communication failures were the primary cause.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 document lack of effective communication and coordination among crew during pushback, supporting the claim of communication/coordination breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in whether procedural deviations or communication breakdowns were primary cause; limited explicit statements on consistent communication failures.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and accessible within the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_dynamic_und_t3_prefinal dataset.

assumptions: The history items provided represent the documented and accessible content within the specified dataset.
No contradictory evidence exists outside the provided history items.
defeaters: If evidence showed the pushback deviation was due to mechanical control failure or environmental marking inadequacy.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence (H4, H8, H10, H12) documents the procedural deviation in pushback execution and its circumstances, confirming the event is recorded and accessible in the dataset. The discriminator evidence favors procedural deviation over communication breakdown, environmental deficiency, or mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit statement confirming dataset accessibility; assumption that the detailed history items represent documented and accessible data.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, including misaligned task execution, delayed responses, and failure to share critical information timely.

assumptions: The lack of warnings and assumptions by crew members indicate communication breakdown rather than deliberate procedural deviation.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, timely communication and coordinated task execution among crew members.
If procedural deviations rather than communication failures were the primary cause.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 describe delayed responses, lack of timely sharing of critical information, and misaligned task execution among crew, supporting the claim of communication/coordination breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity exists in interpreting whether actions were procedural deviations or communication breakdowns, but evidence favors communication issues.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with the key features and operational parameters specific to the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_dynamic_und_t3_prefinal context.

assumptions: Assuming that the TRP markings and environmental conditions described are representative of the Boeing 737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25 operational context.
Assuming that the procedural deviation is distinct from environmental or mechanical causes as per discriminator definitions.
defeaters: If evidence showed that the TRP markings were inadequate or not visible, or that environmental factors were the primary cause, this would change the assessment.
If mechanical control failures or communication breakdowns were documented as primary causes, the procedural deviation alignment would be less supported.

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H8, H13) indicates that environmental factors such as small TRP size and lack of mandatory marshalling wands contributed to the incident, supporting that the procedural deviation aligns with key features and operational parameters of the Boeing 737-8AS context.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity exists regarding the adequacy of visual signals and environmental markings, and the exact influence of crew communication.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution withstands scrutiny against potential counterarguments or exceptions within the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_dynamic_und_t3_prefinal scope.

assumptions: No mechanical control failure occurred as no evidence suggests otherwise.
The tug instructor's statements about control and signals are accurate and complete.
defeaters: If evidence of equipment fault or bench check failures were found indicating control malfunction.
If new testimony showed the tug instructor was unaware or unable to control the tug properly.

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8 and H12 indicate no mechanical control failure was detected and the tug instructor controlled the pushback, supporting that the procedural deviation withstands scrutiny against mechanical failure counterarguments.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct mechanical fault evidence is presented; assumptions rely on operator statements and absence of contrary evidence.

node.statement: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew resists alternative interpretations or defeaters, as no other factors sufficiently explain the observed coordination failures in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_dynamic_und_t3_prefinal data.

assumptions: Crew members' statements about their perceptions and actions are accurate and complete.
No unreported mechanical or environmental factors contributed significantly to the event.
defeaters: If evidence showed that the TRP markings were unclear or misleading to all crew members, or if hardware faults contributed to the event, this would challenge the communication breakdown explanation.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 show that communication and coordination failures among crew members, including lack of warnings and assumptions about actions, explain the coordination breakdown better than alternative explanations such as marking deficiencies.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity remains about the exact situational awareness of all crew members and the sufficiency of visual signals, but no evidence supports alternative causes.
